msContents.summary:
1 fol. on parchment; Shelfmark: Arabe 324 (b); Qurʾānic Text: Q 3:139-146; Lines per page: 12; Script style: kūfī (type C.I.a); Dimensions: 540 x [600] mm; Estimated date of production: 700-800 (?).
The catalogue of the Qurʾānic manuscripts of the French National Library gives the following information (Déroche, 1983: p. 75): "Arabe 324 b : fo 3. Fo 3 : III, 139-146. Copie anonyme et non datée. Graphie C I a. Diacritiques : quelques traits obliques ; vocalisation absente. Une main plus récente a ajouté, à la première et à la dernière ligne de chaque feuillet, la transcription en écriture cursive du début et de la ﬁn du texte. Pas de séparation des versets. Parchemin. 1 feuillet. Page : 540 x [600]. 12 lignes. Réglure à la pointe sèche au r du feuillet. Encre noire. Surface d’écriture : 478 x [530]."
Datation: The date of Arabe 324 (b) remains uncertain: With regard to the script style kūfī C in the typology of François Déroche (Déroche 1983: p. 75-77), the codex was presumably produced during the 8th century. As Shebunin (Куфический Коран Хедивской Библиотеки в Каире, "The kufic Qurʾān in the Khedival Library in Cairo”) mentions 248 leaves of the original codex, 34 folios (parchment) written by a later scribe, 61 leaves of other parchment Qurʾāns as replacement of missing folios it is possible that many fragments have been produced later after the 8th century maybe in order to replace damaged or lost leaves. Carbon dating of samples from the Paris fragments Arabe 324 (a), Arabe 324 (c) and 324 (d) supports this idea. Eléonore Cellard mentions in a twitter message on January 4, 2020 that carbon dating of samples from Arabe 324a, Arabe 324c and Arabe 324d gives the following results: “…Ar.324c (between 660-780). The others are later: Ar.324a is from the 11th-12th, and 324d is from the beginning of the 12th- beginning of the 13th” ( twitter message on January 20, 2020). Based on this evidence fragments Paris Arabe 324 (c) and Gotha Ms. orient. A 462 are to be considered as leaves of the original codex, whereas Paris Arabe 324 (a) and Arabe 324 (d), are likely supposed to be pages that have been produced later.
